content: The Act titled "Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007" provides provisions regarding providing material support to facilitate, reward, or encourage acts of terrorism. The "Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007" amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, by adding a new section prohibiting the provision of material support to facilitate, reward, or encourage acts of terrorism. Offenders can face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment if death results. Jurisdictional bases include offenses affecting interstate or foreign commerce. The Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007 prohibits providing support for acts of terrorism that impact interstate or foreign commerce. Offenders can face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment if death results. Jurisdictional bases include the use of mails or facilities of interstate or foreign commerce, intent to influence US government policy, and violation of US criminal laws. The Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007 prohibits supporting acts of international terrorism within the United States or abroad. Offenders can face severe penalties, including fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment in cases of death. Jurisdictional bases include intent to influence US government policy and violation of US criminal laws. The Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007 prohibits supporting acts of international terrorism within or outside the United States. Offenders can face severe penalties, including fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment in cases of death. Jurisdictional bases include intent to influence US government policy and violation of US criminal laws. The term 'material support or resources' is defined in the section, and the perpetrator of an act includes any person who commits the act. The Counter-Terrorism and National Security Act of 2007 prohibits supporting acts of international terrorism within or outside the United States. Offenders can face severe penalties, including fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or life imprisonment in cases of death. The term 'material support or resources' is defined in the section, and the perpetrator of an act includes any person who commits, aids, abets, counsels, commands, induces, or procures its commission, attempts, plans, or conspires to commit the act. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to acts of international terrorism. Title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions related to acts of international terrorism, such as receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization and providing material support for acts of terrorism. The amendments also address prohibiting attempts and conspiracies to obtain military-type training and address kidnapping and rape overseas. Section 2332 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a new subsection (c) that addresses kidnapping of a national of the United States outside the country. The amendment specifies fines, imprisonment, and potential death penalty for offenders. The amendment to section 2332 of title 18, United States Code increases the maximum penalty for kidnapping a national of the United States outside the country to 25 years imprisonment. SEC. 5. HOSTAGE TAKING. Section 1203 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to address hostage taking, including seizing or detaining individuals with threats of harm to compel actions. The amended Section 1203 of title 18, United States Code, addresses hostage taking by punishing those who compel actions through threats of harm with imprisonment or death. It is not an offense if the conduct occurred outside the United States unless the offender or victim is a U.S. national, the offender is found in the U.S., or the targeted governmental organization is the U.S. Government. The amended Section 1203 of title 18, United States Code, addresses hostage taking by punishing those who compel actions through threats of harm with imprisonment or death. It is not an offense if the conduct occurred outside the United States unless the offender or victim is a U.S. national, the offender is found in the U.S., or the targeted governmental organization is the U.S. Government. The term 'national of the United States' is defined in section 101(a)(22) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 6. INTERFERENCE WITH FLIGHT CREW OR THREAT TO SAFETY OF AIRCRAFT. Amends Section 46504 of title 49, United States Code to impose fines or imprisonment for individuals who pose a serious threat to aircraft safety. SEC. 7. INCREASED PENALTIES FOR PROVIDING MATERIAL SUPPORT TO TERRORISTS. SEC. 7. INCREASED PENALTIES FOR PROVIDING MATERIAL SUPPORT TO TERRORISTS. Amends Section 2339D of title 18, United States Code to increase penalties for providing material support to terrorists to a minimum of 3 years and a maximum of 15 years in prison. Additionally, SEC. 8. DENIAL OF FEDERAL BENEFITS TO CONVICTED TERRORISTS. Adds Section 2339F to deny federal benefits to terrorists. SEC. 2339F states that individuals convicted of a Federal crime of terrorism will be ineligible for any Federal benefits as determined by the court. This section defines 'Federal benefit' and amends the table of sections for chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. Rule 41(b)(3) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to allow multidistrict search warrants in terrorism investigations, including international terrorism, domestic terrorism, and Federal crimes of terrorism. The amendment allows for warrants to be issued in districts where terrorism-related activities may have occurred. Penalties for obstruction of justice in terrorism cases are increased from 8 to 10 years under title 18 of the United States Code. SEC. 10. SOLICITATION TO COMMIT A CRIME OF VIOLENCE OR TERRORISM. Section 373 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include Federal crimes of terrorism and expand the scope of individuals covered under the law. The amendment to Section 373 of title 18, United States Code includes Federal crimes of terrorism and expands the scope of individuals covered under the law by adding the words "or terrorism" after "solicitation to commit a crime of violence". SEC. 11. TERRORIST OFFENSE RESULTING IN DEATH. Sec. 2339E of Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, introduces a new offense for terrorist acts resulting in death. Offenders who cause a person's death during a terrorist offense can face the death penalty or life imprisonment. The term 'terrorist offense' includes felony offenses defined in specific sections of the law or any attempt or conspiracy to commit such offenses. The table of sections in Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new item related to committing an offense described in paragraph (1). SEC. 12. Death penalty for certain terror related crimes, including offenses resulting in death. The text outlines amendments to various sections of the United States Code to include the death penalty as a punishment for offenses related to nuclear weapons, missile systems, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the variola virus. SEC. 13. INCREASE IN CERTAIN PENALTIES. Amends penalties in various sections of title 18, United States Code, increasing them from 20 years to 30 years and from 10 years to 20 years. SEC. 14. MODERNIZATION OF STATE OF MIND REQUIREMENT FOR SECTION 2339C OFFENSES. Changes the requirement from "unlawfully and wilfully" to "knowingly." SEC. 15. WIRETAP PREDICATE. SEC. 15. WIRETAP PREDICATE amended by striking ``section 2332'' and inserting ``chapter 113B'' in title 18, United States Code.
